Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Astronomy and Atmospheric Science at MIT Haystack Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) and Teachers (RET) Site in Astronomy and Atmospheric Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Haystack Observatory. The program will provide opportunities for undergraduate students and teachers from around the country to actively engage in front-line research in many areas of astronomy, geodesy, and atmospheric science. Program participants will work with individual faculty members and/or observatory staff on focused research projects that last 10 weeks during the summer. The program emphasizes an end-to-end exposure to the research process for the participants. Many of the students will become co-authors on articles published in scientific journals. The very nature of an REU/RET site results in a broader impact, in terms of educational activities. To help broaden the diversity of this program, student and teachers from within Puerto Rico will also be able to participate in this program through a collaboration with Universities within the Ana G. Mendez University System.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the REU/RET program is to provide a research experience for undergraduate students and to help teachers create content within their teaching plans that will encourage students to pursue a career in scientific fields. The Haystack program has hosted ~40 undergraduates over a 5 year period, supporting 10-week summer research projects that have spanned a broad range of radio science topics. The ~10 RET participants developed lesson plans that were refined over a 1 year period, and which have been made available to schools and teachers nationwide. Each year, all program participants, both REU and RET, attended an extensive lecture series presented by Haystack staff, providing in-depth coverage of Haystack research, and allowing students to better understand and appreciate the work of their peers in the program. 

A significant fraction of the undergraduate participants presented oral or poster presentations of their summer projects at major science conferences, and several of them were co-authors on published journal articles based on their projects, and continued to work with Haystack staff for an extended period after the end of the summer program. In many cases, the students significantly advanced the state of important research efforts at the Observatory, and became integral members of the staff research team for a few weeks. All students in the program delivered high quality presentations of their work to a wide Observatory audience in the final week of the program, thereby developing valuable skills of organization prioritization, and public speaking. 

Feedback from the students was consistently positive throughout the duration of the award. The feedback indicated that the experience at Haystack facilitated their understanding of the nature of research, and provided information that helped them make informed career decisions. For some it provided reassurance in their planned pursuit of a Ph.D program and a research career, while for others it convinced them that another path was more appropriate. A particular feature of the program was the addition of Puerto Rican high school senior students under separate funding, which offered the REU participants an opportunity to assume an informal mentoring role.

The teachers who participated in the program were without exception engaged and motivated, showing a high level of interest in the scientific and technical materials to which they were exposed. This translated into well thought out, imaginative lesson plans that blended their education expertise with the infectious enthusiasm for the science that the teachers picked up during interaction with the Observatory staff. These plans were made available on the Haystack website and various other locations on the web, have been described at professional society meetings, and flyers have been distributed at educational events.
